label: paragraphs
cypher:
UNWIND $batch AS row
                MERGE (p:Paragraph {id: row.id})
                SET
                    p.text = row.text,
                    p.title = row.title,
                    p.line = row.line,
                    p.chunk_idx = row.chunk_idx,
                    p.parent_heading = row.parent_heading

batch.text: '''Monica Cecilia Abbott''' (born July 28, 1985) is a retired American professional softball player. Abbott was an All-American pitcher for the [[Tennessee Lady Volunteers softball|Tennessee Lady Volunteers]] in college before starting a professional career in the [[National Pro Fastpitch|NPF]] and in the Japan Softball League. In international competition, she has played for Team USA from 2005 including the national softball team winning a silver medal at the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008]] and [[2020 Summer Olympics]]. Abbott is the NCAA Division I leader in wins, strikeouts, shutouts and innings.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott was born in [[Santa Cruz, California]] and grew up in [[Salinas, California]]. Abbott attended [[North Salinas High School]] from 1999 to 2003; her parents are Bruce and Julie Abbott, and her siblings are Jessica (born 1984), Jared (born 1988) and twins Bina and Gina (born 1991).<ref name="utsports">{{cite web |url=https://utsports.com/sports/softball/roster/monica-abbott/3864 |title=Monica Abbott |location=Utsports.com |access-date=2020-08-27 |archive-date=June 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200629014923/https://utsports.com/sports/softball/roster/monica-abbott/3864 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: While at North Salinas, Abbott led the Vikings to three CIF Central Coast Section Division I titles, averaging more than 300 strikeouts per season.<ref name="californian">{{cite web |url=https://www.thecalifornian.com/story/sports/2017/03/09/monica-abbott-setting-standard/98980664/|title=Monica Abbott: Setting The Standard |location=The Californian|access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott won the Cal-Hi Softball Athlete of the Year, the Sports Focus Athlete of the Year, the state's large school Player of the Year, and the MVP trophies from her high school, conference, county and section. She was also a two-time recipient of The Salinas Californian Athlete of the Year.<ref name="utsports" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Much sought after by many colleges, Abbott decided to go to the University of Tennessee, with their treatment of female athletes an influencing factor.<ref name="californian" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott pitched for the [[University of Tennessee]] Lady Volunteers softball team from 2004 to 2007 and majored in communications.<ref name="utsports" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott became Tennessee's first All-American when selected as a Louisville Slugger/NFCA First Team All-American. In 59 appearances, Abbott was 45–10, compiled a 1.03 earned run average with 44 complete games and 24 solo shutouts, four no-hitters and a perfect game. She struck out 582 batters in 352 innings. Following the season she was named [[Southeastern Conference Softball Freshman of the Year|SEC Freshman of the Year]]. Abbott became the third pitcher in NCAA history to notch 500 strikeouts in a season.<ref name="utsports" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott  became a two-time first-team Louisville Slugger/NFCA All-American and All-South Region selection after going 50–9 with a 0.52 ERA in 392.0 IP.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She broke her own record for single season wins with 50 and had 603 strikeouts thus becoming the first pitcher in NCAA Division I history to record 500 strikeouts in a season twice in her career. She helped lead UT to its first WCWS and was named to the WCWS All-Tourney team.<ref name="utsports" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Once again, Abbott was chosen as a first-team Louisville Slugger/NFCA All-American as well as a first-team All-South Region choice.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She led UT to the WCWS and was chosen as WCWS All-Tournament.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott's 531 strikeouts made an unprecedented third year in a row of over 500.<ref name="utsports" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott struck out  an NCAA Single Season current Record of 724 batters.<ref name="ncaarewatched">{{cite web |url=https://wwwcache.ncaa.com/news/softball/article/2020-06-04/monica-abbott-rewatched-one-her-2007-wcws-games-and-her-reactions-are-golden?amp |title=Monica Abbott rewatched one of her 2007 WCWS games and her reactions are golden |location=NCAA |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She had 23 no-hitters and six perfect games and was named the 2007 [[USA Softball Collegiate Player of the Year]] and the Women's Sports Foundation Sportswoman of the Year award for Team Sports athletes.<ref name="Sportswomen of the Year ">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/2007-10-15-3446696963_x.htm |title=Golfer Lorena Ochoa, softball star Monica Abbott win Sportswomen of the Year awards from WSF |last=Murphy |first=Melissa |date=October 15, 2007 |work=USATODAY.com |publisher=Gannett Co. Inc. |access-date=January 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name="ncaarewatched" />  She also was the 2007 Honda Award Winner.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nfca.org/divnews/general/abbott-wins-honda-award-for-softball-3278 |title=Abbott wins Honda Award for softball|date=June 12, 2007 |location=NFCA |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She guided UT to its first SEC title and a berth in the CWS championship, where they lost to top-ranked Arizona in the best-of-three series final. Once again she was named to the all-tournament team.<ref name="Monica Abbott">{{cite web |url=http://dailydsports.com/monica-abbott/ |title=Monica Abbott|date=July 28, 2017 |location=Daily Dose |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott set career and single season NCAA records her senior season with 189 victories, 2,440 strikeouts, 112 shutouts, 253 appearances and 1,448.0 innings pitched.<ref name="ncaarewatched" /> She set a Single Season Record in Strikeouts of 724.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://utsports.com/news/2013/2/28/ut_legend_monica_abbott_to_have_jersey_retired.aspx |title=UT Legend Monica Abbott to have jersey retired |location=UT Sports |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott was the first pitcher in NCAA Division I history to record 500 strikeouts in all four years of her collegiate career.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She was inducted in the Tennessee Athletics hall of fame.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.knoxnews.com/story/sports/college/university-of-tennessee/other-sports/2017/10/13/justin-gatlin-monica-abbott-part-tennessee-athletics-hall-fame/758398001/ |title=Justin Gatlin, Monica Abbott part of Tennessee Athletics Hall of Fame |location=Knox News |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She was Tennessee's first softball All-American in school history and was named to the All-Women's College World Series team three times.<ref name="teamusaathletes">{{cite web |url=https://www.teamusa.org/usa-softball/athletes/Monica-Abbott |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809010732/http://www.teamusa.org/usa-softball/athletes/monica-abbott |url-status=dead |archive-date=August 9, 2014 |title=Monica Abbott |location=Teamusa.org|access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott enjoyed tremendous success internationally between 2005 and 2010.  She led Team USA to four World Cup of Softball championships, three Canada Cup titles, and gold medals at both the 2006 and 2010 ISF Women's World Championships.  Abbott pitched the United States to a gold medal at the 2007 Pan Am Games in Rio.<ref name="Monica Abbott"/>   Abbott stepped down from the US Softball National Team in 2010 but returned in 2018 where she helped the USA win another World Championship.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wbsc.org/news/softball-brings-people-together-it-belongs-in-the-olympics|title=USA Softball Star Monica Abbott "Softball brings people together, it belongs in the Olympics"|location=WBSC|access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>  She was also a member of the team that won the 2018, 2019 USA Softball International Cup, 2018 & 2019 Japan Cup and 2019 Pan Am Games.<ref name="teamusaathletes" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott was selected for the final 15-person Olympic squad as one of three pitchers. On August 11, 2008, Abbott made her Olympic debut for Team USA, pitching the final inning against Venezuela. Abbott then pitched a 5 inning perfect game, striking out 8, as Team USA defeated the Netherlands 8–0. This was the first perfect game pitched in the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Sports_News/2008/08/17/USA-gets-perfect-game-from-Abbott/56171218981304/ |title=USA gets perfect game from Abbott |location=UPI| access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: In pool play, Abbott pitched the US to a 7–0 victory against Japan. She then pitched against them in the semi-final securing the 4–1 win and  USA's place in the gold medal game.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Team USA met Japan in the gold medal game and lost 3–1. Abbott pitched the final two innings.<ref name="teamusaathletes" />><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.teamusa.org/USA-Softball/Team-USA/History/Women/2008/Olympic-Games/Olympic-Games-Box-Scores/Gold-Medal-Game |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302034749/http://www.teamusa.org/USA-Softball/Team-USA/History/Women/2008/Olympic-Games/Olympic-Games-Box-Scores/Gold-Medal-Game |url-status=dead |archive-date=March 2, 2014 |title=Gold Medal Game|location=Team USA| access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>   She finished the Olympics with a 0.29 ERA and a 3–0 record in 24 innings pitched while striking out 32 batters.<ref name="teamusaathletes" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott agreed to be a part of the Olympic squad,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.espn.com/espnw/sports/story/_/id/24020275/softball-star-monica-abbott-return-team-usa-quest-olympic-gold|title=Global ace Monica Abbott on her return to Team USA and her quest for Olympic gold|date=July 10, 2018 |location=ESPN |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>  softball's first appearance at the Olympics since 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.softballamerica.com/stories/for-monica-abbott-2020-olympics-offers-chance-at-redemption/|title=For Monica Abbott, 2020 Olympics Offers Chance At Redemption|location=Softball America|access-date=2020-08-27|archive-date=August 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200812092650/https://www.softballamerica.com/stories/for-monica-abbott-2020-olympics-offers-chance-at-redemption/|url-status=dead}}</ref>  The Olympics were postponed to 2021 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.<ref>{{cite web
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.montereyherald.com/2020/03/31/monica-abbott-of-salinas-staying-sharp-despite-summer-olympics-postponement/|title=Monica Abbott of Salinas staying sharp despite Summer Olympics postponement|date=March 31, 2020|location=Monterey Herald |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott started in three matches for Team USA in the [[2020 Summer Olympics]] group stage against Canada, Australia, and Japan. In addition, she came in as the relief pitcher for group stage matches against Italy and Mexico as well as in the gold medal match against Japan. She pitched 20.1 innings with 31 strikeouts, 7 hits, and a 0.00 ERA. Team USA lost to Japan 2–0 in the gold medal match and Abbott earned a silver medal along with the rest of the team.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://olympicsoftball.wbsc.org/en/2021/e-2021-softball-olympic-games/teams/USA/players/74687|title = United States}}</ref> Following the tournament, she was named onto the WBSC All-Olympic softball team.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wbsc.org/news/japans-yamato-fujita-named-tokyo-2020-softball-mvp-as-all-olympic-team-revealed|title=Japan's Yamato Fujita named Tokyo 2020 softball MVP as All-Olympic team revealed}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott has been a member of five winning NPF teams, being named MVP in all those championships. She was also a NPF runner-up in 2009 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/05/476901885/softball-pitcher-monica-abbott-signs-record-1-million-contract|title=Softball Pitcher Monica Abbott Signs Record $1 Million Contract |website=NPR |date=May 5, 2016 |location=NPR| access-date=2020-08-27|last1=Wagner |first1=Laura }}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott debuted in the [[National Pro Fastpitch|NPF]] on August 2, 2007, by striking out a career best 18 batters in a 10-inning victory against the [[Rockford Thunder]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.profastpitch.com/news/npfnews/index.html?article_id=878 |title=Washington, Abbott Knock Off Osterman, Thunder |location=Web.archive.org |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905142454/http://www.profastpitch.com/news/npfnews/index.html?article_id=878 |access-date=2020-06-29|url-status=usurped |archive-date=September 5, 2015 }}</ref> They won the 2007 NPF Championship, vs Rockford when Abbott threw a no hitter in the final.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nfca.org/divnews/general/glory-celebrates-first-npf-championship-3258|title=Glory Celebrates First NPF Championship |date=August 27, 2007 |location=NFCA| access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: In 2009 she played for the USSSA Pride as a runner up and in 2010 was traded to the Tennessee Diamonds.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://utsports.com/news/2010/5/4/Monica_Abbott_and_Shannon_Doepking_Traded_to_NPF_s_Tennessee_Diamonds.aspx |title=Monica Abbott and Shannon Doepking traded to NPF's Tennessee Diamonds|location=UT Sports |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>   She signed as a free agent  with the Chicago Bandits from 2011 to 2015.<ref name="Monica Abbott"/>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: On July 23, 2015, Abbott pitched her second perfect game as a member of the [[Chicago Bandits]], beating the [[Dallas Charge]], 10–0.<ref>{{cite web |author1=NPF |title=Bandits Rout Charge Behind Abbott's Perfect Game |url=http://www.sportspagemagazine.com/content/os/sb-os/c-sb-os/art-c-sb-os/bandits-rout-charge-behind-abbotts-perfect-game.shtml?63463 |website=SportsPageMagazine.com |access-date=July 27, 2015 |date=July 24, 2015 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910044145/http://www.sportspagemagazine.com/content/os/sb-os/c-sb-os/art-c-sb-os/bandits-rout-charge-behind-abbotts-perfect-game.shtml?63463 |archive-date=September 10, 2015  }}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: In May 2016, the [[Scrap Yard Dawgs]], a [[National Pro Fastpitch]] team, signed Abbott to a six-year contract, believed to be worth $1 million<ref>{{cite web |last=Hays |first=Graham |title=Monica Abbott Wants Change After Signing $1 Million Contract with NPF Expansion Team |url=https://www.espn.com/espnw/sports/story/_/id/15464430/pitcher-monica-abbott-signs-1-million-contract-national-pro-fastpitch-expansion-team |website=[[ESPNW.com]] |date=May 5, 2016 |access-date=May 5, 2016}}</ref> and the highest salary paid by a professional women's sports team in the United States.<ref name="cfmco">{{cite web |url=https://www.cfmco.org/monica-abbott-an-inspiration-on-and-off-the-field/|title=Monica Abbott: An Inspiration On and Off the Field |date=July 14, 2013 |location=CFMCO| access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: For her career she is the most decorated pitcher in the league history with five Pitcher of The Year awards and 9 All-NPF Team selections. Currently, she also holds the career wins and strikeouts crowns (the second pitcher to achieve each milestone and the only to have both) along with the no-hitters (6), shutouts record (also the only pitcher to cross the 40 and 50 total). She also ranks top-10 in ERA, WHIP, innings and strikeout ratio (10.1).
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: In 2010, Abbott joined the Japan Softball League (JSL). In her first season abroad, she led the circuit in strikeouts, ERA and was named league MVP while leading her [[Toyota Red Terriers|Toyota]] team to the Japan Softball League title.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailydsports.com/monica-abbott-2/#:~:text=In%202010%2C%20Abbott%20joined%20the,the%20Japan%20Softball%20League%20title.|title=Monica Abbott|date=August 10, 2018|location=Daily Dose|access-date=2020-08-27|archive-date=January 29, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200129174533/http://dailydsports.com/monica-abbott-2/#:~:text=In%202010%2C%20Abbott%20joined%20the,the%20Japan%20Softball%20League%20title.|url-status=dead}}</ref>    She pitched a perfect game in the final, then threw a no-hitter in the championship game the following year to lead Toyota to back-to-back titles. Toyota went on to threepeat for the JSL titles in 2010, 2011, 2012.<ref>{{cite web
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: he JSL titles in 2010, 2011, 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flosoftball.com/articles/5058197-monica-abbott-leads-toyota-red-terriers-to-japan-softball-league-title |title=Monica Abbott Leads Toyota Red Terriers to Japan Softball League Title|date=November 28, 2016 |location=Flo Softball |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She was a 5x MVP winning in 2010, 2011, 2012, 2016, 2018)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wbsc.org/news/toyota-motors-red-terriers-clinches-japan-softball-league-monica-abbot-named-mvp |title=Olympic pitchers battle for Japan Softball League title, Monica Abbott named MVP|location=WBSC |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: As of 2020, she is in her 11th season.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: At Tennessee she wore #7 and it was retired by Tennessee.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://utsports.com/news/2013/2/28/ut_legend_monica_abbott_to_have_jersey_retired.aspx |title=USA softball pitcher Monica Abbott's long wait for Olympics delayed at least another year |location=UT Sports |access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.knoxnews.com/story/sports/college/university-of-tennessee/other-sports/2020/03/24/olympics-usa-softball-pitcher-monica-abbott-lady-vols/2912386001/ |title=UT Legend Monica Abbott to have jersey retired |location=Knox News |access-date=2020-09-02}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott founded the Monica Abbott Scholarship fund to support the education of female multi-sport athletes who demonstrate leadership both in the classroom and on the field. In addition, she hosts clinics with young softball players across the United States.<ref name="cfmco" /> Abbott hosts about 16 different instructional clinics for children under the age of 18 each year. As demand for more clinics has gotten stronger, Abbott is planning to introduce an online academy to help her reach more youth. The academy will feature video tutorials that go in-depth into the three focuses of Abbott's pitching style: rise ball, power pitching, and basic mechanics and leg drive.<ref name="frontofficesports2020">{{cite web |url=https://frontofficesports.com/monica-abbott-softball-2020/ |title=Team USA's Monica Abbott Growing American Softball Amidst The Sport's Olympic Return |date=December 16, 2019 |location=Front Office Sports |access-date=2020-08-27 |archive-date=December 8, 2021
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Her fans are called Moniacs.<ref name="frontofficesports2020" />
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott is simultaneously the NCAA Division I leader in Victories (189), Shutouts (112), Strikeouts (2,440), Single-Season Strikeouts (724) and innings pitched. During her senior season in college, she set the record for the most strikeouts in a Division I softball season.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: She also holds the career records in wins, strikeouts, no hitters and shutouts for the National Pro Fastpitch.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: In Japan, Abbott was a 6-time champion and a 5-time MVP. She is currently a member of the independent "This is Us" team.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thisisussoftball.com/athletes |title=This Is Us Athletes |location=Thisisussoftball.com |access-date=2020-06-28}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: Abbott is in the Guinness Book of Records with the fastest softball pitch ever, reaching 77 miles per hour back on June 16, 2012, in a National Pro Fastpitch (NPF) game between Abbott's Chicago Bandits and the Carolina Diamonds.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/fastest-womens-softball-pitch |title=Fastest Softball Pitch (Female)|location=Guinness World Records|access-date=2020-08-27}}</ref>
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * [[NCAA Division I]] tied-2nd highest 7-inning strikeout total of all-time (20), set on March 26 of her freshman year vs Liberty University
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * 6 games of at least 17 strikeouts in a 7-inning game, a mark only accomplished 20 times in NCAA Division I history (including Abbott's performances)
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * 2007 [[USA Softball Collegiate Player of the Year]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * Only Player with more than one 50-win season in a career (2)
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * Only Player with four seasons of 40+ wins in a career
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * Only Player with four 500-strikeout seasons (and two 600-strikeout seasons) in a collegiate career
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * Most games pitched in a season (2005) – 69
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * Most wins and most strikeouts in a season by a freshman (2004) – 45 wins and 582 strikeouts
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * 2,440 career [[NCAA Division I Softball career strikeouts list|NCAA Division I strikeouts]] (1st all-time)
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * 189 career [[NCAA Division I Softball career wins list|NCAA Division I wins]] (1st all-time)
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * 23 career NCAA Division I no-hitters (2nd all-time)
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * 6 career NCAA Division I perfect games (2nd all-time)
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * Pitched First Perfect Game in Olympic History
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * Women's Sports Foundation Sportswoman of the Year (2007)
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: * First pitcher in D1 to record 500 Strikeouts all 4 seasons at the collegiate level.
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: |+[[United States women's national softball team|Team USA]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: | title = Monica Abbott—awards, championships and honors
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: [[Category:Softball players at the 2007 Pan American Games]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: [[Category:Softball players at the 2019 Pan American Games]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: [[Category:Pan American Games gold medalists for the United States in softball]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: [[Category:Olympic silver medalists for the United States in softball]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: [[Category:Olympic softball players for the United States]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott

batch.text: [[Category:Southeastern Conference Athlete of the Year winners]]
batch.title: Monica_Abbott
